Forest.name: Bengal Tiger
Forest.description: The Bengal tiger is a majestic big cat native to the Indian subcontinent. Known for their distinctive orange coat with black stripes, these apex predators are powerful swimmers and excellent hunters.
Forest.diet: Carnivore - primarily deer, wild boar, and water buffalo
Forest.habitat: Tropical rainforests, grasslands, and mangrove swamps
Forest.lifespan: 8-10 years in wild, up to 20 years in captivity
Forest.funFact: Tigers are the largest cat species and can leap up to 5 meters high!

Forest.name: Asian Elephant
Forest.description: Asian elephants are intelligent, social animals with remarkable memory and emotional depth. They play a crucial role in their ecosystem by creating water holes and dispersing seeds.
Forest.diet: Herbivore - grasses, bark, roots, and fruits
Forest.funFact: Elephants can recognize themselves in a mirror, showing self-awareness!

Forest.name: Red Panda
Forest.description: Red pandas are adorable tree-dwelling mammals with reddish-brown fur and a long, bushy tail. Despite their name, they're not closely related to giant pandas.
Forest.diet: Herbivore - primarily bamboo, also fruits and insects
Forest.funFact: Red pandas spend most of their time in trees and use their tail as a blanket!

Ocean.name: Bottlenose Dolphin
Ocean.description: Bottlenose dolphins are highly intelligent marine mammals known for their playful behavior and complex social structures. They use echolocation to navigate and hunt.
Ocean.funFact: Dolphins have unique whistles that act like names to identify each other!

Ocean.name: Green Sea Turtle
Ocean.description: Green sea turtles are large marine reptiles that migrate thousands of miles between feeding grounds and nesting beaches. They play a vital role in maintaining healthy seagrass beds.
Ocean.funFact: Sea turtles can hold their breath for up to 5 hours underwater!

Ocean.name: Great White Shark
Ocean.description: Great white sharks are apex predators with powerful jaws and keen senses. They're crucial for maintaining balance in marine ecosystems.
Ocean.diet: Carnivore - seals, sea lions, fish, and dolphins
Ocean.funFact: Great whites can detect a single drop of blood in 100 liters of water!

Desert.name: Dromedary Camel
Desert.description: Dromedary camels are remarkably adapted to desert life with their single hump storing fat for energy. They can survive extreme temperatures and go weeks without water.
Desert.diet: Herbivore - thorny plants, dry grasses, and saltbush
Desert.funFact: Camels can drink 40 gallons of water in one go and store it in their bloodstream!

Desert.name: Fennec Fox
Desert.description: Fennec foxes are the smallest fox species, famous for their enormous ears that help dissipate heat and detect prey underground. They're perfectly adapted to desert life.
Desert.diet: Omnivore - insects, small mammals, birds, and plants
Desert.funFact: Their huge ears can be half as long as their body and help them stay cool!

Desert.name: Meerkat
Desert.description: Meerkats are highly social mongooses that live in complex underground burrow systems. They take turns standing guard while others forage, displaying remarkable cooperation.
Desert.diet: Omnivore - insects, lizards, birds, and roots
Desert.funFact: Meerkats are immune to certain snake venoms and teach their young how to hunt!

Arctic.name: Polar Bear
Arctic.description: Polar bears are the largest land carnivores, perfectly adapted to Arctic life with thick fur and a layer of blubber. They're excellent swimmers and primarily hunt seals on sea ice.
Arctic.diet: Carnivore - primarily ringed and bearded seals
Arctic.habitat: Arctic sea ice and coastal areas
Arctic.funFact: Polar bear fur isn't actually white - it's transparent and hollow to trap heat!

Arctic.name: Arctic Fox
Arctic.description: Arctic foxes have incredibly thick fur that changes color with seasons - white in winter, brown/gray in summer. They can survive temperatures as low as -70Â°C.
Arctic.diet: Omnivore - lemmings, birds, fish, and berries
Arctic.funFact: Arctic foxes have fur on their paw pads to keep them warm on ice!

Arctic.name: Emperor Penguin
Arctic.description: Emperor penguins are the tallest and heaviest penguin species. Males endure harsh Antarctic winters, fasting for months while incubating eggs on their feet.
Arctic.funFact: Emperor penguins can dive to depths of 500 meters and hold their breath for 20 minutes!
